38409199.review:
In the 08 May 2015 article "The 25 Best Puzzle Games Ever Made,"

https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2015/05/08/best-puzzle-games/

"Sokobond" made number 21 on that list.  I disagree.  If you really, really like Sokobon-type puzzles and would like to see a chemistry twist to those, then the 144 levels in this game (124 regular and 20 bonus) should keep you going for a while.  But, I had issues with it ranging from my own mistaken desires on up (or down, as the case may be).  From least important to more important:

- This one's my own fault.  When I bought this, I figured it would be more of a way to see how molecules got built within a game framework.  Instead, it's a Sokobon-type game using clumps of atoms as the "blocks" that you move around until you get the final molecule.  "Sokobon" as most of the name ought to have clued me in.  So, just disregard this one.

- The interface is keyboard only.  It would be a lot easier on the wrists if we could use the mouse to move things around.

- The progression through the game is indicated by the filling in of a periodic table.  For whatever reason, the periodic table used appears to be wrong.  Even taking into consideration the developer's desire for contiguous pieces in that table, their version still appears to contain four extra elements.  Sort of odd in a game based around chemistry.

- There's no "proper" progression through the puzzles.  I'd have thought the puzzles would start with the simplest molecules (restricted to the organic set of Hydrogen, Carbon, Nitrogen, and Oxygen (they throw in Helium, but it appears to be a type of mobile blocker to the puzzle since it doesn't bond with anything) and work up from there.  Instead, there's only a fairly general increase in molecular complexity.  Similarly, it's fairly open which order you proceed through that periodic table of puzzles.  So, at any given moment you might be working with different atoms, different complexity, and different game mechanisms to build things.

- I'd expected more of an educational bent to the game:  show us the molecule, explain what it does and what bonds the atoms use, and, perhaps, talk about the geometry and how it's built in reality.  Instead, we're presented with a puzzle space containing some atoms, we move them around in such a way that they'll fit through the blocks, and when you get everything stuck together, you're presented with a blurb about the molecule.  The atoms stick together based on their valence electrons and there's some work with single, double, and triple bonds.  But, none of that is ever explained.

- The above is also a problem because unless you know enough chemistry to know what the end product will be (there are 40 molecules used in the game) when shown a list of atoms, you really don't know what you're trying to build.

So, as I said above, even ignoring my mistaken pre-purchase impression of what the game was, I'm not recommending it.

37593874.review:
Sokobond is an old-school puzzle game. It is simple, it is hard and it is good fun if you're into challenges.

The game is controlled via keyboard only, even in the main menu, which may seem odd at first. It's probably part of a certain old-school aesthetic and will become second nature to you after a few minutes. The ruleset is surprisingly simple: There are circles with open docking ports in a confined space. You are one of them. Move and push circles around until all docking ports are filled, creating larger structures of circles.

The natural beauty is that this simple, incredibly logical ruleset is based on how chemistry works in real life. In chemical terms: You are an atom and move other atoms around until all atoms have their outer electron shells filled via molecular bonding. Chemistry knowledge is not required to beat the game, but it certainly helps, giving you an intuitive idea of what your target molecule will be. After creating it the game will reward you with interesting chemical factoids and more levels.

I really enjoyed the streamlined minimalist design and the non-existent load times. The game is technically rock solid and never caused any problems. It's fascinating to see how long a very basic mechanic can be kept interesting with good level design. I wasn't a fan of this kind of puzzle and honestly pretty bad at it, but I gradually got better and started enjoying the game more. There are 124 basic levels followed by 20 very very hard bonus levels. Of the 15 hours I played, I spent about half on these last levels, sometimes coming back to the same level across several days to try out new ideas. Thankfully the game is very forgiving, having no time limits and allowing infinite undos and resets, so you can experiment to your heart's content.

Among my gripes is that the progression is pretty bumpy. The difficulty of any basic level seemed utterly random. The game gradually introduces more mechanics (double bonds, noble gasses as spacers, bond breaking, etc.) and I would have liked a little more control over that. Some mechanics I really enjoyed and would have liked more of, but there may only be a hand-full of levels. Sadly there's also no endless mode or level generator, which would have been a great addition, especially to get some more relaxing, easy levels.

Beating the last levels felt really really good, but there was some frustration and annoyance here and there through-out the game due to the high difficulty and due to being forced to play levels/mechanics I didn't enjoy. I'm not sure I would pay full price for this game, but I can definitely recommend picking it up during a sale, if you're into mind-bending movement-based old-school puzzles.

35896341.review:
这是一个看起来是化学，其实是推箱子的游戏。
游戏的目的是吧不同的元素连在一起，每种元素可连的数量和它最外层的电子数量有关。
比如氧可以连2个，氢可以连1个，两个氢和一个氧连在一起可以变成水，就可以通关了。

游戏关卡的排布正好是个元素周期表，每个色块的关卡都有各自的特点。
音乐其实只是一般，但音效特别迷人，有时就为了听连起来的音效来回走，很魔性。

游戏的巧思在很多地方都有体现，有些关卡甚至不止一种过法，是一款非常有意思的解谜游戏。

游戏的关卡设计也是需要提的一点，在我心中大概在第1.5梯队左右的样子，非常优秀，但离卓越还有一丝距离。
游戏的难度本身是不小的，但本身的潜力没能完全发挥出来。
其中有一个小细节，当一个元素同时有机会和两个元素相连但只能选一个时，它会选缺电子更多的那个，因为化学中这种情况的元素夺电子的能力更强，更容易反应（化学生勿喷），这是个非常好的设定，但相关的关卡却不多，只在附加关里用到了一下，并没有出彩的利用这个特点的关卡。

不过对我这种智障已经够难了，最后几关是看攻略的，非常惭愧。

过关后还有相关化学小知识，有点意思。

总之这是个非常值得一玩的解谜游戏。
以上（8分/10分）

34004682.review:
Excellent puzzle game based on pushing and linking atoms to form molocules. You don't need to know anything special about chemistry, it's just the framework for a set of devious puzzles. The core of the game is pushing around blocks, sokoban style, except they form bonds, linking to each other. As you progress some puzzles feature multiple bonds, splitting and reconnecting atoms, and rotating molocules till you have just the right shape to reach that one last atom you need. Every level ends with a bit of chemistry trivia about the molocule you just created.

Most puzzles aren't trial and error or brute force, but tempt you into making assumptions that keep you from spotting an elegant solution, which makes solving them very very satisfying.

As you can see from the screenshots, graphics are purely functional, but in a puzzle game that's not a bad thing.

32340391.review:
I have yet to be dissappointed by Alan Hazelden's elegant puzzle games. Typical of his style, Sokobond employs simple, self-explanatory mechanics in a series of small, self-contained puzzles which nevertheless manage to be frustratingly challenging.

The difficulty builds up naturally -- each new mechanic is introduced on its own, first with simple levels to give you an idea of the basic tricks, and then with harder levels. Then, the different mechanics are brought together in later puzzles. Stopping to think logically through the situation is a must; if you don't, you get stuck trying things that don't work over and over, and many levels seem impossible.

The chemistry theme is well done, supported by random chemistry facts after each level. The graphics are smooth and aesthetically pleasing. The overall atmosphere is relaxing and minimalist.

One drawback is that there are some levels where repeated guesswork leads to the solution. When I beat these levels, I had no idea what I did or what the key to solving them was. I realize that guessing is not the smartest way to play a difficult puzzle game, but I am sure many players will guess anyway. Another minor drawback is that bonding order is unclear -- if you push a molecule next to two things it could bond with, which bonds first? This ends up being relevant in several puzzles, but there is no explanation so you just have to try and see what happens.

[i]Update:[/i] It took 15 hours to finish the game including all the bonus levels. I did look up one solution, in the end (the last one I was stuck on).

29567523.review:
Wie der Name schon impliziert, ist [i]Sokobond[/i] vom Prinzip her so ähnlich wie [i]Sokoban[/i]. Jedoch werden hier anstatt Kisten Atome beziehungsweise Radikale umhergeschoben. Ziel ist es, am Ende ein Molekül zu erschaffen, dass keine ungepaarten Valenzelektronen mehr hat. Das mag jetzt erstmal kompliziert klingen, ist es aber (zumindest prinzipiell) nicht. In jedem Level übernimmt man die Kontrolle über ein Atom und geht Bindungen mit anderen Atomen ein, indem man sie berührt (oder im Falle von Helium indem man sie in die Nähe von anderen Atomen schiebt), und zwar solange, bis jedes Elektron jedes Atoms (dargestellt durch einen kleinen Kreis am Rand des Atoms) eine Bindung eingegangen ist. In den ersten Leveln geht das noch recht direkt vonstatten, aber später kommen noch andere Spielmechaniken hinzu, wie Doppel- und Mehrfachbindungen, oder die Möglichkeit, die Ausrichtung der Atome zu verändern.
Jede dieser Spielmechaniken wird im ersten Rätsel, in dem sie vorkommt, erklärt. Somit wird auch jemand, der keine Anung von Chemie hat, schnell verstehen, was zu tun ist.

Auch die Benutzeroberfläche ist stark am Thema Chemie orientiert. Die Level werden zum Beispiel über eine Art Periodensystem ausgewählt, welches selbst auch in Untergruppen unterteilt ist. In diesen farblich gekennzeichneten Untergruppen werden die Level zusammengefasst, die ähnliche Spielmechaniken beinhalten (wie zum Beispiel das Erschaffen und Aufspalten von Mehrfachbindungen). Diesem Designelement ist es zu verdanken, dass mit dem Lösen eines Levels mehrere neue Level freigeschaltet werden. So kann man sich, falls einem ein Rätsel mal zu schwer ist (was mehrmals der Fall sein wird), erstmal an einem anderen probieren.

Das Spiel präsentiert sich in minimalistischer Optik (man sehe sich die Screenshots auf der Shopseite an), die das Wesentliche auf den Punkt bringt, und nicht vom Spiel selbst ablenkt. Untermalt wird das Ganze von entspannenden ambienten Klängen. Somit kann man sich voll und ganz auf die Rätsel konzentrieren und sich schön den Kopf zerbrechen.

[h1]Fazit[/h1]
Ideal zum Entspannen geeignet.
Wer gerne Rätselspiele spielt, und der Chemie nicht vollends abgeneigt ist, wird mit [i]Sokobond[/i] für ein paar Stunden seinen Spaß haben.

25731771.review:
When I hear Zach Barth say that a puzzle game made him want to stab himself, I expect that game to be made from the stuff of Satan's nightmares. As it turns out, Sokobond is made from more palatable material, and Zach's quote is made from hyperbole. This is not a criticism, mind you - when you have 124 puzzles in your game, you don't want inordinately difficult roadblocks impeding access to the rest of them. Progression is handled by way of a grid in which each puzzle is represented by a square and successfully completing it unlocks adjacent squares. The challenge curves out nicely, and if there was one puzzle I had grown tired of there were usually at least a half dozen others I could divert myself to.

The trailer shows you pretty much everything you need to know about the game mechanics. In every puzzle you take control of a single molecule which has a certain number of bonds it can make - anywhere from 1 to 4 - and will automatically bond with any molecule it comes into contact with, provided that that molecule also has spare bonds available. If it doesn't, then you are able to push that molecule elsewhere in the level. At fixed points in the environment are spaces which will separate bonded molecules, increase the strength of molecules' bonds (i.e. if 2 molecules are bonded, and each have another bond spare, running them through such a space will remove the spares by giving them a double bond), and reorientate the molecules' positions. That's it. It's essentially a block-pushing game with a novel twist.

The goal is to connect all of the provided molecules in such a way that there are no remaining bonds. In some levels the challenge lies in working out in what order and in what arrangement a small number of molecules need to be collected and placed to use all their bonds, while in others the challenge lies in piloting a huge snaking line of molecules around a very limited space, making sure that certain parts of its body never touch others in order to avoid undesired bonds. Some levels even see you take control of helium, which has 0 bonds available, meaning that you can only create the end product indirectly, via environmental manipulation. Though, as other reviewers have pointed out, the chemicals you will be making are frequently the same, the way in which you make them is always fresh and different - no small feat, given the amount of content on offer.

I enjoyed my time with Sokobond and would recommend it to anyone looking for an intermediate level of challenge. It's certainly not even in the same universe of hellish difficulty as Zachtronics games. It's not the most amazing or memorable puzzle game I've ever played, but it is thoughtful and well designed.

Overall score: 3.5/5

As a footnote, I'd like to say that I did not enjoy the bonus levels unlocked upon completion of the other 124, however as they are presented in the context of a bonus this did not affect my opinion of the game one way or the other. I will talk about them anyway, because they serve to illustrate the difference in 'feel' regarding the sort of puzzles I enjoy, which is useful info if you share similar preferences. The bonus levels adhere to the 'needle in a haystack' school of puzzle design, in which there is only one route to the solution and a single misstep will render the puzzle unsolvable, however this will not be apparent until several steps further down the line, leaving you to wonder which of the many previous moves you have made was the wrong one. With a few exceptions, the main game's puzzles allow you enough leeway to experiment and come upon an 'a-ha!' moment organically, and if it has become unsolvable this will be immediately apparent. The latter feels as if I'm slowly being guided to a solution via process of elimination, while the former gives no feedback whatsoever, making it more frustrating than fun. The great majority of the puzzles in Sokobond are fun.

Sokobond is a nice little puzzle game with some questionable views of chemistry. 

The game involves you controlling one atom in a grid structure, and you move the atom around the grid forming bonds with other atoms [or not, in the case of noble gases]. Each atom is a simplified representation of its real-world counterpart, focusing mostly on the number of bonds it can form.

The puzzles in this game range from simple to quite tricky, and it took me quite a few hours to complete the entire thing without cheating. [Don't cheat, it's very satisfying when you solve a puzzle]. The mechanics require you to do a lot of lateral and reverse thinking, which is quite good.

Simple graphics and sound design, which works well for a puzzle game. The controls use either a keyboard or a controller, both of which are again, very simple [LUDR + undo/reset].

Definitely a good simple [but not easy] puzzle game.

Sokobond ist ein Spiel bei welchem man chemische Elemente miteinander Verbinden muss um ein neues Element zu erstellen. Es gehört zur Spielgenre der Slider-Puzzle bei welchem es gilt die Spielelemente in einer bestimmten Reihenfolge zu bewegen um am Ende die gewünschte Verbindung aller Elemente zu erhalten.

Dabei sind die Elemente Teilweise so positioniert, dass es manchmal nur einen Weg gibt sie miteinander zu verbinden. Neben der Positionierung der chemischen Elemente sind auch Blöcke und Elemente zum Trennen der Verbindungen in den Welten verteilt. Die Blöcke erschweren dem Spieler bei bereits verbundenen Teilen das Bewegen in der Welt. Kommt der Spieler an einen Punkt an dem er mit der gewünschten Verbindung nicht mehr fortfahren kann, kann er die vorherigen Schritte Rückgängig machen oder das Level komplett neu starten.

Am Ende eines jeden Levels wird dem Spieler eine Information zu dem kreierten Element gezeigt. Was ist Ammoniak und wofür wird es in Unserer Umwelt gebraucht. Auf diese Weise hat man neben dem Spielspaß auch noch die Möglichkeit etwas zu lernen. 

Das Design des Spiels ist einfach gehalten und macht durch die Farbwahl sehr viel Spaß. Durch die Animationen, den Infos nach jedem Spiel mit zusätzlichen Illustrationen und den schön designten Rätseln ist das Spiel sehr empfehlenswert!

17864620.review:
Sokoban (not to be confused with Sokobond, the game I'm reviewing) is a puzzle originating from Japan (hence the japanese-sounding name). It's a fairly simple puzzle that tends to have overwhelmingly convoluted solutions. You control a person in a warehouse, and your job is to put all the boxes away into designated places. They are heavy, so you can only move them by pushing them around. You can't move through boxes, and you can't push a box if there's a wall or another box behind it. Simple rules, incredibly complex solutions.

Sokobond takes this premise and adds chemistry to the mix. You control an atom, and your goal is to get all the valence electrons in all the atoms to bond. For example, you might control a Hydrogen, and another Hydrogen and an Oxygen are somewhere. Your goal would therefore be to bond both Hydrogens to the Oxygen to make water. Or mayble you'll control a carbon amidst another carbon and six hydrogens to make ethane.

Just like Sokoban, in Sokobond, you have a maximum of four options available to you at any time: move up, move down, move left, or move right. Just like Sokoban, if you try to move into an atom, you'll push it. Unlike Sokoban, if two atoms with free valence electrons become adjacent, they will bond, and bonded atoms will move as a group.

Later, you'll be introduced to three more puzzle elements: debonders which remove a bond you made, rebonders which add another bond to a pair of atoms (allowing for molecules like ethene or acetic acid), and rotators, which let you rotate bonds.

Just like Sokoban, Sokobond has a simple premise, but loads of depth, and all those extra-convoluted solutions.

Sokobond est un jeu de réflexion sympathique où la résolution de puzzles se fait par l'assemblage d'atomes pour former des molécules dans un espace restreint, avec des obstacles et/ou des contraintes.

Aucune connaissance particulière en Chimie n'est requise pour jouer à ce jeu tant ses mécaniques de gameplay sont efficaces et clairement établies (le nombre de liaisons possibles pour chaque atome est symbolisé par le nombre de boules blanches gravitant autour de chacun d'eux : 4 pour le carbone C, 3 pour l'azote N, 2 pour l'oxygène O, 1 pour l'hydrogène H et 0 pour l'hélium He).

Pour 10€, vous aurez accès à plus d'une centaine de niveaux dont 20 tableaux bonus à la difficulté (très) relevée (la communauté Steam a heureusement produit des guides de qualité pour les plus impatients).

Par ailleurs, chaque fin de niveau est ponctuée d'une anecdote, parfois drôle, autour de la molécule assemblée.

Je recommande donc ce jeu à toutes les personnes aimant, en premier lieu, les puzzle games, et, en second lieu, à celles qui sont curieuses à propos de la Chimie.

16090970.review:
This is a really great puzzle game. I've never played sokoban (which this is based off of if it's not obvious to you), but it's a great spin on the concept, as instead of just being able to push things, you can pull atoms around when you bond with them (but bonding in the wrong pattern can make the puzzle unsolvable if you can't bypass an obstacle as that shape). You can infinitely undo any number of actions, so if you get into an unsolvable scenario you don't have to start over, just undo the last X steps until you can try something else.

The mechanics that let you rotate a bond, make more bonds and split bonds are well executed, and they often get in your way just as much as they help you complete the puzzle, which makes you have to figure out just the right set of moves to execute.

I resorted to a guide for a couple puzzles, as I had an idea of what I needed to make happen but I didn't know how to get there. Despite this, I thought each puzzle was well designed and none of them felt impossible; I just needed a hint to nudge me in the right direction. 

I hope the developers add steam workshop support with a puzzle editor; I'd love to play more levels. Definitely get this if you at all like puzzle games!

14764669.review:
Sokobond is a neat puzzle game.  You start with a board with a finite amount of space, and a single piece (an ion) that you can move.  Move it next to another ion and the two will bond.  Bind all the free ions together to make some compound and you're done.  The thing is you can neither rotate your molecule, nor unbind ions, and the board is designed such that you have to be careful how you bind the first ions or you won't be able to get your molecule to bind with the last ions (the molecule'll be too fat to maneuver).  Sounds simple, and the early puzzles are, but they get harder.

Successfully create a molecule, and you get a little blurb about what that compound is, and how it's used.  Chemistry ftw!

Your progress through the puzzles is tracked on a grid with one puzzle per grid block.  Solve a puzzle and the adjoining puzzles become available.  You start in a red area with red puzzles.  Finishing the puzzles leading to an arrow opens up a new, differently colored grid section.  Sometimes the different colors offer new mechanics, sometimes they just offer harder puzzles.

The graphics are as good as they need to be.  The sound is adequate.  The background music is the ambient, puzzle-game sort (think World of Goo).  It's unobtrusive enough not to bother you while you're trying to figure your moves, but keeps you from listening to nothing.

You don't need any chemistry knowledge for this, but you'll certainly pick some up.  The amount of free electrons an ion has is indicated by floating circles slowly orbiting it.  This is the sort of thing that gets ingrained in a mind over time after moving nitride and oxide ions around for fun. 

This game is cool for its elegant simplicity, and because chemistry, yay!

Interesting puzzle game. 

Unlike Sokoban, which is a block-pushing game... here, you push atoms which can form bonds when two atoms are adjacent to each other, with an objective to form a single coherent molecule involving all the atoms (or, in some levels, multiple molecules).  Various puzzles have noble gasses (which don't bond with anything else), locations on the grid which break bonds, locations which strengthen bonds (double-bonding and triple-bonding, for instance), and locations which bend your molecules.

Later levels can be very, very non-obvious.

13527476.review:
Sokobanin laatikonsiirtelyn kuvittelisi olevan puzzlepuolella jo aikalailla puhki kaluttu ajatus, mutta Sokobond todistaa muuta. Se on kaikinpuolin tyylikäs näkemys Sokoban-puzzleista, ja lainaa ideansa kemiallisista sidoksista. Siirreltävänä on staattisten laatikkojen sijaan atomeja, joilla on atomista riippuen nollasta useampaan vapaata elektronia. Kun kaksi atomia joilla on vapaa elektroni päätyvät vierekkäin, syntyy sidos. Jokaisen kentän tarkoituksena on luoda tarjolla olevista atomeista kokonainen molekyyli ilman ensimmäistäkään vapaata elektronia.

Hyville puzzlepeleille tyypilliseen tapaan perusajatusta aletaan monipuolistaa uusilla käänteillä kun perusjutut ovat hallussa. Kaksois-, kolmois- ja neloissidoksia, sidosten purkamista, molekyylien kääntelyä, heliumin tapaisia inerttejä atomeja. Puzzleja ei kasvateta pelin edetessä massiivisiksi vaikeuden lisäämiseksi, vaan aikalailla kaikki ovat mukavan pieniä, hallussa pysyviä.

Kemia on Sokobondissa ennenkaikkea teema eikä mitään kovaa tiedettä tarvita, vähän samaan tapaan kuin erinomaisessa SpaceChemissä. Siinä missä SpaceChem nojasi enemmän järjestelmien rakentamiseen ja optimointiin, on Sokobond kuitenkin kevyempi puhtaasti Sokoban-puzzleihin nojaava aivopähkinä. Biokemisti tykkää!

Overall: Good
Difficulty: Very high

Likes:
- Gradually introduces a variety of game mechanics (breaking bonds, compound bonds, rotation, inert atoms, and combinations of these) which keep things interesting and increases difficulty
- Later puzzles are very challenging
- Great sound effects

Dislikes:
- The more complicated puzzles feel less tightly designed because there are so many possible moves that look like they might lead to the solution.  This is especially true since you are not given what the goal molecule should look like, so often you can't even tell if you are headed in the right direction.
- I personally prefer logic puzzles, and these Sokoban-style puzzles rely more on spatial reasoning

12644495.review:
My brain is now puzzled.  Even though you don't need any understanding of chemistry what so ever, if you enjoy puzzle games this game is most certainly for you.

At first glance, we may be reminded of the classic Atomix from the Amiga and C64 era. Apart from building molecules, this is an entirely different game that feels very unique and genuine. The staggering 144 levels will keep you busy for quite some time as it took me about 12 hours to beat. The puzzles themselves are easy enough for the average person to beat while not feeling silly doing so and difficult enough to challenge every mind. The basic premise is controlling one atom to move, bond, break, turn other atoms to complete a molecule - all within a set of boundary. The only letdown is atom variety as you'll only be seeing C, O, H, N and He which can and will get boring once you're close to completing the game.

It is worthy of mentioning that the game runs on Adobe Air and there have been reports coming from Linux users that it does not run on some occasions as Adobe has ceased linux support.
Although the game would greatly benefit from Steam Workshop integration, the developer has stated he does not wish to implement such features in the foreseeable future - a shame as user created levels would keep the game and its community alive for longer.

For the fan of the puzzle genre, Sokobond will quench a thirst for simple 2D puzzlers. The average gamer should give it a try as its addictive nature may surprise you playing it more and more. If you have a personal vendetta against these types of games - stay clear of this one.

Sokobond est un merveilleux Sokoban pondu par Draknek et finaliste de plusieurs festivals de jeu vidéo.

11506422.review:
Sokobond is a puzzle game with a learning twist. You see not only are you trying to reunite, or combine the different objects in the level, but these objects are actual periodic elements, and you are putting them together to create different chemical compounds. All I have to say is who knew science could be so fun? You will be faced with level after level of differing elements and obstacles to overcome. If you successfully put all the elements together not only do you unlock additional levels, but you get to learn about the compound you just created.

Graphically you are not going to see anything 3D, but in this puzzle game, the beauty of the simplicity of the graphics shows that this is definitely more about the elements. All the colors are varying subtle colors such as red, green, yellow, blue, etc. The levels are laid out in a grid base format where you will be trying to combine the elements by moving up, down, left, and right. The little added pieces to the game also come off as subtle, but are very recognizable after you use that functionality the first time. The pieces I'm talking about are the - and + which will take away bonds, or add bonds.

The music and sounds follow the same path as the art style. It is a soft sound that gets other sounds added in when you make a bond, or lose a bond.

The controls, as described before, are simply moving up, down, left, and right.

So here's a game that has no story, but has many rewards to be had. The rewards you gain are that you complete a level, open up other levels, and if you so choose you can learn something about the compound you just made. As the levels increase, the difficulty increases. There are many many levels to sink your teeth in, and for those parents out there you can not only educate your kids with this game, but you can secretly help out if you have a controller plugged in. The best part about this puzzle game is that the developers did not want to stop the chance for someone to learn about all the different compounds, so there is an option in the menu that allows you to unlock all the levels.

I personally found this game a breath of fresh air, I did not have to worry about monster attacking, or having to watch certain statistics to make sure I could survive a level. I was able to play at my own pace, and hell I actually relearn some stuff that I had long forgotten about. So with that I have to give this game a 9.5 out of 10.

11469690.review:
I can say that I'm probably not even halfway through this game, and I've found it rather addicting.

I could say that my first exposure to Sokoban, the inspiration for this, would be through the arcade game Pengo and a non-visual example in Zork III. (Yes, I'm showing my age. Get off my lawn.) Sokobond takes it a step further by having you maneuver different atoms to form bonds and ultimately get a molecule form them all, with the exception of the helium atoms. The challenge lies in the space to move for each board, and in later levels, the placement of certain features, like bond splitters, bond enhancers, and rotators. Be prepared for a mental workout, though, as levels will range from 'piece of cake' all the way to 'dear God, are you freaking KIDDING ME??'

The game itself is minimalist, as advertised. Controls are simple, graphics are not fancy, and sound consists occasional beeps with a slight droning chord in the background. The focus on this puzzle game are the puzzles themselves, with a little bit trivia to go along at the end of each puzzle with that feeling of a job well done. Total game time-- as well as the amount of Angrish used while playing-- will vary with the gamer.

All in all, this is a solid puzzle title and well worth having in one's collection.

11359651.review:
I've found this game on notonsteam.com and instabought it, worth it.

The mechanics are based on 倉庫番 (sōkoban) which is a type of transport puzzle.
In this game, the player will push atoms (displayed as Lewis' Ionic dot structure) to form molecules (Lewis Theory of Bonding). 
After completing the task, it will display a small info card about that completed molecule.
It is pretty educational but if the molecule repeats, it won't give you any new factoid :(

The sound of this game is just special and unique. The feedback sounds are diffused amazingly in the ambient background, building up a very calm scenario. For a non time-based puzzle, I didn't expected such good sound works. But like the molecules information, the sounds are very limited too.

The game progression is very simple, it follows the complexity of the molecules. The maps can be solved using single-agent search algorithm. But sokoban are known as NP-hard problems (Non-deterministic Polynomial-time hard). The puzzles can exponentially grow the branching factor of the moves which can be very challenging.

Sokoban can be a very entertaining way to keep your brain active but cannot be considered a game for the casual.
Interested in more sokoban? please visit the official site: http://www.sokoban.jp

11353468.review:
Below, you'll find a [b]comprehensive 4 minute review of Sokobond[/b] in video format. Should you prefer to read, just skip the link and read the notes below.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uMl_h2qUXNI&list=UUft3ypJdQ_aiUT8h8_HzjYQ
Sokobond features a minimalistic and yet slick artstyle, underlined by great, atmospheric music (by Rob Roth, who you might know from Starseed Pilgrim and Electronic Super Joy). The gameplay is a block-pushing puzzler at it's very core, however with increased bonding, your molecule grows larger and thus movements gets restricted. This unique twist adds fresh flavour to the genre and without much knowledge in chemistry, you'll soon find a lot of intriguing fun facts thrown towards you for completing level after level. The game does grow very challenging later on, but only after you grew accustomed to the basic mechanics. Progression is well done. I do have some minor gripes with the rather classical Helium levels and some levels that require larger molecules, nontheless, overall Sokobond is a [b]very good[/b] game and should be picked up by fans of the genre. The average gamer should wait for a sale though, as Sokobond is not ground breaking, however competent in what it wants to achieve.

11238350.review:
In an era where "innovation" means adding micropayments to a 15-year-old franchise, Alan Hazelden finds a unique mechanic, dresses it up in a design so crisp it comes with vinaigrette dressing on the side, and presents it like it's something he does all the time. Which it is, because he's some sort of puzzle-game-making superhuman.

If you don't play this game, you're not allowed to say you enjoy puzzle games to anyone ever again.

40543314.review:
A very good puzzle game with lots of levels and new mechanics added throughout the game to keep the player interested. 

I must admit that the last hours weren't as enjoyable as the first ones though, for two reasons. First, I think that after the game stops adding new mechanics and after playing some levels that combine all of them the game becomes repetitive. This repetitivity doesn't mean that the game gets easier at the end though, and this is my second point: the last levels (especially the bonus ones) were a bit too tough for me. The game doesn't give you any hint, so I was glad to see there are some guides on Steam and complete walkthroughs on Youtube, because I would never have finished the game without them, and the completionist in me would just have been angered with the game. 

That being said, I'm not particularly good at puzzles, let alone Sokobans, so a more experienced player (or just someone who doesn't mind being stuck hours on a level) might enjoy the game a bit more than I did.
